content:
I need some help on this PR. Some careful review of the semantic changes, from someone familiar with the results in question would be appreciated.

But I also need some advice. Since there's a lot of changes to LaTex syntax, I'd ideally want to somehow build the documentation so that I can view the result and make sure it looks as intended. Is this easily doable?
#29464
I have to say that I'm not particularly excited about reviewing changes where the author isn't even confident they're correct.

That is fair. I'd like to do most of the reviewing work myself, but as per my request for advice, I'm a little bit blocked. If you have any input on that, it would be great.

At this point I am confident about all changes except the ones going from code highlighting to LaTeX, and the ones changing expressions. These I need to find a good way of verifying. All the purely textual changes seem fine to me.
Is the best way to go about this review, perhaps, to paste the LaTex bits into some external LaTex renderer?

Is there a way to split that PR (by commits, or by kind of change)? 90 lines is long when I want to review careful for five different kinds of changes at once. And as you see, at least some of these changes are somewhat controversial.

You did make LLM-driven docs PR that were helpful; I'm not opposed to them in principle. But if you make changes you're not confident in, that runs a high risk of being a huge drain on everybody's time (including yours).
Your contributions are appreciated; I wonder if there's a more effective way for you to support mathlib.

Harald Husum said:

At this point I am confident about all changes expect the ones going from code highlighting to LaTeX, and the ones changing expressions. These I need to find a good way of verifying. All the purely textual changes seem fine to me.

That sounds like you're proposing a natural split of the PR. That seems useful to me.
I left a comment about the unicode -> LaTeX changes. I propose you extract these into a separate PR, so they can be bikeshed there.

I think making precursor PR(s) with all the trivial stuff makes sense. I can do that.

I do, in general, feel bad about PRing content I'm not confident in. I made an exception here because I needed advice on how to go about this confidence building (ref. "how do I build the docs?"), and I thought that was best done with a concrete PR to discuss.
Thank you very much for being transparent about this PR. The maintainer team will discuss this and try to come up with a clear policy about such cases.

Ok, two four precursor PRs are ready. I'll cut out more of them when I get time:

  • #29471: em dashes in Akra-Bazzi
  • #29473: Three hashes in sectioning docstrings
  • #29479: Moving misplaced documentation
  • #29498: Text changes I am confident in

Until grep or ripgrep or git grep gets NKFD support (unlikely), I'd prefer ascii characters for keywords as opposed to "correct" style. We even do this for terms like Bezout's lemma, spelling it both with and without the diacritics
I could address that by adding the regular-hyphen-version to the tags of the relevant files, right? Or would that not cover your use cases?

Here's another one: #29479

This isolates the most nontrivial change of the original PR. This moves misplaced documentation of definitions to the locations where the documentation actually belongs.
@Yakov Pechersky I now added a wide selection of tags to the files in the PR you were (presumably) referring to. Let me know whether that works for you.

Yet another precursor PR. This one seems to have bikeshedding potential, judging by the response on the original PR.

#29498: All the text changes I am sure I prefer over the original docs, not covered by the previous three precursor PRs.
I like almost all the changes here (and have commented on two that could imho be tweaked or reverted).

Regarding grepping em dashes, I'm not sure which one I prefer, but I want to advocate for consistency:
I regularly search for such theorems by copy-pasting their em dashed name from Wikipedia into the GitHub search box, and swapping the em dash with a hyphen. I swap because I know Mathlib uses dashes.
Currently searching for \b[A-Z][a-z]+-[A-Z][a-z]+\b in all of mathlib4's *.lean files (regex & match case) I get 1,339 results, and switching to an em dash I get 115 results.
If you're advocating for swapping to em dashes, then I suggest swapping all of the 1,339 results and not just Akra-Bazzi, because that just creates an inconvenient limbo for greppers (115+22 is worse than 115).
Are we talking about en dashes – U+2013 or em dashes — U+2014
I think en dashes but OP's PR called them em dashes so I went along with it (actual em dashes seem pretty rare in Mathlib)
Sorry about the confusion: I did mean en dashes, not em dashes.

As for your point about consistency @Snir, I think it is a goal that one should not have to think too hard about which dash one searches for, which is why my PR introduces tags that are using both the hyphen and the en dash. That should mean that you'll be able to locate Akra–Bazzi no matter how you search.

Doing so makes it acceptable, in my mind, to make this change only for Akra–Bazzi and not all similarly named theorems.

That said, I agree that this is a change that makes sense to do universally. But I'm unsure whether the best way to do so is by way of a single huge PR.
